It is characterized by its dense, clustered fronds that form a compact rosette structure, which helps it retain moisture in its native habitat. The plant produces small, delicate spore-bearing structures called sporangia, which are typically located on the underside of the fronds. Its leaves are usually bi- or tri-pinnate, with a finely divided, feather-like appearance. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, Pycnophyllopsis keraiopetala is considered a sensitive indicator of undisturbed, humid environments.
